Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: Dhritarashtra said, "What did my people and the sons of Pandu do when they had assembled together, eager for battle, on the holy plain of Kurukshetra, O Sanjaya?"

Questions: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?
Answers: Sanjaya said: Having seen the army of the Pandavas drawn up in battle array, King Duryodhana approached his teacher, Drona, and spoke these words.

Questions: What did Duryodhana say to his teacher, Drona?
Answers: Behold, O Teacher! This mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arrayed by the son of Drupada, thy wise disciple.

Questions: Which warriors from the Pandava army did Duryodhana first talk about?
Answers: Here are heroes, mighty archers, equal in battle to Bhima and Arjuna, Yuyudhana (Satyaki), Virata, and Drupada—all mighty warriors.

Questions: Who was the king from Kashi who fought in the Mahabharata war?
Answers: Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the valiant king of Kasi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Saibya—the best of men.

Questions: Which other warriors from the Pandava army did Duryodhana talk about?
Answers: The strong Yudhamanyu and the brave Uttamaujas, the son of Subhadra (Abhimanyu, the son of Subhadra and Arjuna), and the sons of Draupadi, all of them great charioteers (great heroes)."

Questions: Why was Duryodhana taking names of all the warriors in the Mahabharata war?
Answers: Know also, O best among the twice-born! the names of those who are the most distinguished amongst ourselves, the leaders of my army; these I name to you for your information.

Questions: Who were the warriors on the Kaurava side that Duryodhana mentioned about?
Answers: "Thou thyself, Bhishma, Karna, Kripa, the victorious in war, Asvatthama, Vikarna, and Bhurisrava, the son of Somadatta—all these are ready for battle."

Questions: What did Duryodhana say about the warriors on his side in the Mahabharata war?
Answers: And also many other heroes, ready to give up their lives for my sake, armed with various weapons and missiles, all well-skilled in battle.

Questions: What did Duryodhana say while comparing his army with the Pandava army?
Answers: Our army, marshalled by Bhishma, is insufficient, whereas theirs, marshalled by Bhima, is sufficient.

Questions: What did Duryodhana ask Drona to primarily do during the war?
Answers: Therefore, do all of you, stationed in your respective positions in the several divisions of the army, protect Bhishma alone.

Questions: What did Bhishma do to cheer up Duryodhana during the Mahabharata war?
Answers: His glorious grandsire, the oldest of the Kauravas, roared like a lion to cheer Duryodhana and blew his conch.

Questions: What happened after Bhishma blew his conch?
Answers: Then, suddenly, conches, kettledrums, tabors, drums, and cow horns blared forth from the Kaurava side, and the sound was tremendous.

Questions: Who was the first person from the Pandava side to blow the conch?
Answers: Then, Madhava (Krishna) and the son of Pandu (Arjuna), seated in the magnificent chariot yoked with white horses, blew divine conches.

Questions: What were the names of the conches of Krishna, Arjuna and Bhima?
Answers: Hrishikesha blew the Panchajanya, Arjuna blew the Devadatta, and Bhima, the wolf-bellied doer of terrible deeds, blew the great conch Paundra.

Questions: What were the names of the conches of Yudhisthira, Nakula and Sahadeva?
Answers: King Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, blew the Anantavijaya; Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughosha and the Manipushpaka.

Questions: Who else fought from the Pandava side?
Answers: The king of Kasi, an excellent archer, Sikhandi, the mighty car-warrior, Dhrishtadyumna, Virata, and Satyaki, the unconquered.

Questions: Who else from the Pandava side blow their conch?
Answers: Drupada and the sons of Draupadi, O Lord of the Earth, and the son of Subhadra, the mighty-armed, blew their conches each separately.

Questions: What was the reaction of Kauravas after the Pandava side blew their conches?
Answers: The tumultuous sound rent the hearts of Dhritarashtra's party, reverberating through both heaven and earth.

Questions: What was depicted on Arjuna's chariot flag?
Answers: Then, seeing the people of Dhritarashtra's party standing arrayed and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna, the son of Pandu whose ensign was a monkey, took up his bow and said the following to Krishna, O Lord of the Earth.

Questions: What did Arjuna first ask Krishna to do in the Mahabharata war?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, place my chariot in the middle between the two armies, so that I may behold those who stand here, desirous to fight, and know with whom I must fight when the battle is about to commence."

Questions: Why did Arjuna want Krishna to draw his chariot between the two armies?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, place my chariot in the middle between the two armies, so that I may behold those who stand here, desirous to fight, and know with whom I must fight when the battle is about to commence."

Questions: What did Arjuna want to observe at the beginning of the war?
Answers: For I desire to observe those who are assembled here to fight, wishing to please in battle the evil-minded Duryodhana—the son of Dhritarashtra.

Questions: Where did Krishna place the chariot?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Thus addressed by Arjuna, Krishna stationed the best of chariots, O Dhritarashtra, in the midst of the two armies.

Questions: In front of whom did Krishna place the chariot?
Answers: In front of Bhishma and Drona, and all the rulers of the earth, he said: "O Arjuna, son of Pritha, behold these Kurus gathered together."

Questions: Which relatives did Arjuna see on the other side in the war?
Answers: Then, Arjuna (son of Pritha) saw there (in the armies) stationed fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, and friends.

Questions: Whom did Arjuna see when Krishna placed his chariot in the middle of the two armies?
Answers: He saw fathers-in-law and friends in both the armies. The son of Kunti, Arjuna, seeing all those kinsmen thus standing arrayed, spoke sorrowfully, deeply filled with pity.

Questions: Seeing whom did Arjuna become emotional during the war?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, seeing my kinsmen arrayed here, eager to fight,

Questions: What happened to Arjuna's limbs when he saw so many relatives in the enemy's army?
Answers: My limbs fail, my mouth is parched, my body quivers, and my hair stands on end.

Questions: What happened to Arjuna's bow when he saw so many relatives in the enemy's army?
Answers: The Gandiva slips from my hand, and my skin burns all over; I am unable to stand, and my mind is reeling, as it were.

Questions: What was Arjuna's reaction when he saw so many relatives in the enemy's army?
Answers: And I see ill omens, O Kesava. I do not see any good in slaying my kinsmen in battle.

Questions: Where in the Gita does Arjuna say that he has no desire for empire or victory?
Answers:
I desire not victory, O Krishna, nor kingdom, nor pleasures.
What use is dominion to us, O Krishna, or pleasures or even life?

Questions: Why did Arjuna say that he has no desire for victory or the empire?
Answers: Those for whose sake we desire kingdom, enjoyments, and pleasures stand here in battle, having renounced life and wealth.

Questions: What did Arjuna say about the way teachers and relatives are to be treated?
Answers: Teachers, fathers, sons, and grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives—

Questions: Where in the Gita does Arjuna say that he will not kill his relatives even if they kill him?
Answers: These I do not wish to kill, O Krishna, even though they kill me, for the sake of dominion over the three worlds; leave alone killing them for the sake of the earth."

Questions: What did Arjuna say will happen if he killed his own relatives?
Answers: By killing these sons of Dhritarashtra, what pleasure could be ours, O Janardana? Only sin would accrue to us from killing these felons.

Questions: What according to Arjuna is the effect of killing our own kin?
Answers: Therefore, we should not kill the sons of Dhritarashtra, our relatives; for how can we be happy by killing our own kin, O Madhava (Krishna)?

Questions: What did Arjuna say about the nature of Kauravas?
Answers: Though they, with intelligence overpowered by greed, see no evil in the destruction of families and no sin in hostility to friends,

Questions: Why did Arjuna want to turn away from the battle?
Answers: Why should we not, who clearly see the evil in the destruction of families, learn to turn away from this sin, O Janardana (Krishna)?

Questions: What did Arjuna say would happen to his family if he kills his own clan?
Answers: In the destruction of a family, the immemorial religious rites of that family perish; on the destruction of spirituality, impiety indeed, overwhelms the whole family.

Questions: What did Arjuna say would happen to the women if he kills his own clan?
Answers: O Krishna, by the prevalence of impiety, the women of the family become corrupt; and, when women are corrupted, O Varshenya (descendant of Vrishni), intermingling of castes arises.

Questions: What leads to hell according to Arjuna?
Answers: Confusion of castes leads to hell for the slayers of the family, for their forebears fall, deprived of the offerings of rice-balls and libations of water.

Questions: What did Arjuna say would happen if there is inter mixing in the clans?
Answers: By these evil deeds of the destroyers of the family, which cause confusion of castes, the eternal religious rites of the caste and the family are destroyed.

Questions: What did Arjuna say would happen to those whose clans are destroyed?
Answers: We have heard, O Janardana, that those men in whose families the religious practices have been destroyed are inevitably destined to dwell in hell for an unknown period.

Questions: Why did Arjuna say that he was about to commit a sin?
Answers: Alas! We are involved in a great sin, for we are prepared to kill our kinsmen, out of greed for the pleasures of a kingdom.

Questions: Why did Arjuna want to be killed by the enemy Kauravas?
Answers: If the sons of Dhritarashtra, with weapons in hand, should slay me in battle, unresisting and unarmed, that would be better for me.

Questions: What did Arjuna do after arguing that he will prefer being killed instead of killing his own relatives?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken in the midst of the battlefield, Arjuna cast away his bow and arrow and, his mind overwhelmed with sorrow, sat down on the seat of the chariot.

Questions: What did Sanjaya say about the state of Arjuna?
Answers: Sanjaya said: To him, who was thus overcome with pity, despondent, with eyes full of tears and agitated, Madhusudana (the destroyer of Madhu) or Krishna spoke these words.

Questions: What were Krishna's first words on seeing the weak state of Arjuna after he refused to fight the war?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "From whence has this perilous strait come upon you, this dejection which is unworthy of you, disgraceful, and which will close the gates of heaven upon you, O Arjuna?"

Questions: What did Krishna say to encourage Arjuna to fight the war?
Answers: Do not yield to impotence, O Arjuna, son of Pritha. It does not befit you. Cast off this mean weakness of the heart! Stand up, O conqueror of foes!

Questions: How can I become strong?
Answers: Do not yield to impotence, O Arjuna, son of Pritha. It does not befit you. Cast off this mean weakness of the heart! Stand up, O conqueror of foes!

Questions: Why was Arjuna reluctant to shoot arrows at Bhishma and Drona?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Madhusudana, how can I fight in battle with arrows against Bhishma and Drona, who are worthy of being worshipped, O destroyer of enemies?"

Questions: Why was Arjuna reluctant to shoot arrows at his teachers?
Answers: Better it is, indeed, in this world to accept alms than to slay the most noble teachers. But if I were to kill them, even in this world, all my enjoyments of wealth and fulfilled desires would be stained with their blood.

Questions: Why was Arjuna reluctant to shoot arrows at Kauravas (sons of Dhrtarastra)?
Answers: I can hardly tell which would be better, that we should conquer them or that they should conquer us. Even the sons of Dhritarashtra, whom we do not wish to slay, stand facing us.

Questions: When did Arjuna first admis that he is confused?
Answers: My heart is overpowered by the taint of pity; my mind is confused as to my duty. I ask Thee: Tell me decisively what is good for me. I am Thy disciple; instruct me, who has taken refuge in Thee.

Questions: Why was Arjuna so grief stricken?
Answers: I do not see that this sorrow that burns up my senses would be removed, even if I were to attain prosperous and unrivaled dominion on earth or lordship over the gods.

Questions: Where in the Gita did Arjuna say that he will not fight?
Answers: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha, the Lord of the senses, Arjuna, the conqueror of sleep and destroyer of foes, said, "I will not fight," and became silent.

Questions: What was Krishna's first reaction on seeing the grief stricken state of Arjuna?
Answers: To him who was despondent in the midst of the two armies, Krishna, smiling, O Bharata, spoke these words.

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "You have grieved for those who should not be grieved for; yet, you speak words of wisdom. The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead."

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?
Answers: Nor, at any time, was I not, nor thou, nor these rulers of men; nor, verily, shall we ever cease to be hereafter.

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: Does the soul transmigrate after death of the body?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: What is transmigration of the soul?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: How do various feelings of pleasure and pain arise?
Answers: The contact of the senses with the objects, O son of Kunti, which causes heat and cold, pleasure and pain, has a beginning and an end; they are impermanent; endure them bravely, O Arjuna.

Questions: What is the sign of a steadfast human?
Answers: That firm man, whom surely these afflictions do not, O chief among men, to whom pleasure and pain are the same, is fit for attaining immortality.

Questions: Where does Krishna talk about impermanence of pleasure and pain?
Answers: That firm man, whom surely these afflictions do not, O chief among men, to whom pleasure and pain are the same, is fit for attaining immortality.

Questions: What is the real and unreal?
Answers: The unreal has no being; there is no non-being of the real; the truth about both has been seen by the knowers of the truth (or the seers of the essence).

Questions: Is there anything that immutable and indestructible in this universe?
Answers: Know that to be indestructible, by which all this is pervaded. No one can cause the destruction of that, the Imperishable.

Questions: Does the Jiva also die when the body dies?
Answers: These bodies of the embodied Self, which are eternal, indestructible, and immeasurable, are said to have an end. Therefore, fight, O Arjuna.

Questions: What is the sign of ignorance in a human?
Answers: He who takes the Self to be the slayer and he who thinks it is slain, neither of them knows. It does not slay, nor is it slain.

Questions: What are the properties of the soul or atman?
Answers: It is not born, nor does it ever die; after having been, it again does not cease to be; unborn, eternal, changeless, and ancient, it is not killed when the body is killed.

Questions: Can a Jiva be killed by anyone?
Answers: Whoever knows it to be indestructible, eternal, unborn, and inexhaustible, how can that person slay, O Arjuna, or cause to be slain?

Questions: Can the soul be killed by anyone?
Answers: Whoever knows it to be indestructible, eternal, unborn, and inexhaustible, how can that person slay, O Arjuna, or cause to be slain?

Questions: What happens to the soul after the body dies?
Answers: Just as a man casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, so too the embodied Self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others that are new.

Questions: Can the soul or self or atman be burnt or destroyed?
Answers: Weapons cannot cut it, fire cannot burn it, water cannot wet it, wind cannot dry it.

Questions: Can the soul be dried up?
Answers: This Self cannot be cut, burned, wetted, nor dried up; it is eternal, all-pervasive, stable, immovable, and ancient.

Questions: Is grieving suitable for even those who do not believe in an eternal soul or self or atman?
Answers: But even if thou thinkest of It as constantly being born and constantly dying, even then, O mighty-armed one, thou shouldst not grieve.

Questions: Why is grieving unsuitable even for those who do not believe in an eternal soul or self?
Answers: For the born, death is certain, and for the dead, birth is certain; therefore, you should not grieve over the inevitable.

Questions: Can you explain the cycle of birth and death?
Answers: For the born, death is certain, and for the dead, birth is certain; therefore, you should not grieve over the inevitable.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: Beings are unmanifest in their beginning, manifest in their middle state, O Arjuna, and unmanifest again in their end. What is there to grieve about?

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: One sees this (the Self) as a wonder; another speaks of it as a wonder; another hears of it as a wonder; yet, having heard, none understands it at all.

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: This indweller in the body of everyone is ever indestructible, O Arjuna; therefore, you should not grieve for any creature.

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: Further, having regard to your duty, you should not waver, for there is nothing higher for a Kshatriya than a righteous war.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: Happy are the Kshatriyas, O Arjuna! who are called to fight in such a battle that comes of its own accord as an open door to heaven.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: But if you will not fight this righteous war, then having abandoned your own duty and reputation, you will incur sin.

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: People will also recount your everlasting dishonor; and for one who has been honored, dishonor is worse than death.

Questions: What do other warriors treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: The great chariot-warriors will think that you have withdrawn from the battle out of fear, and you will be held in low esteem by those who have held you in high regard.

Questions: What do the enemies treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: Your enemies, scoffing at your power, will speak many abusive words—what could be more painful than this?

Questions: What would have happened if Arjuna lost the Mahabharata war?
Answers: Slain, you will obtain heaven; victorious, you will enjoy the earth; therefore, stand up, O son of Kunti, resolved to fight.

Questions: How can Arjuna make sure that he does not incur any sin by fighting the war?
Answers: Having made pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat equal, engage in battle for the sake of battle; thus, you shall not incur sin.

Questions: Where does Krishna start telling about Karma Yoga?
Answers: This, which has been taught to you, is wisdom concerning Sankhya. Now listen to wisdom concerning Yoga, endowed with which, O Arjuna, you shall cast off the bonds of action.

Questions: Does the practice of Karma Yoga protect from evil?
Answers: In this, there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm produced, nor any transgression. Even a little of this knowledge protects one from great fear.

Questions: How to get rid of fear?
Answers: In this, there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm produced, nor any transgression. Even a little of this knowledge protects one from great fear.

Questions: How is the nature of the mind and intellect of a Karma Yogi?
Answers: Here, O joy of the Kurus, there is only one single-pointed determination; many-branched and endless are the thoughts of the indecisive.

Questions: What happens to people who are engrossed in the rituals of the Vedas?
Answers: The unwise, taking pleasure in the eulogizing words of the Vedas, utter flowery speech, saying, "There is nothing else," O Arjuna.

Questions: What is wrong with people who are engrossed in the rituals of the Vedas?
Answers: Full of desires, with heaven as their goal, (they speak words that are directed to ends) leading to new births as the result of their works, and prescribe various methods abounding in specific actions, for the attainment of pleasure and power.

Questions: What is the greatest limitation of people whose minds cling to pleasure and power?
Answers: For those who are attached to pleasure and power, whose minds are drawn away by such teachings, their determinate reason is not formed which is steadily bent on meditation and Samadhi (superconscious state).

Questions: What are the characteristics of a person who is free from the three Gunas?
Answers: The Vedas deal with the three attributes; be thou above these three attributes. O Arjuna, free yourself from the pairs of opposites and ever remain in the quality of Sattva, freed from acquisition and preservation, and be established in the Self.

Questions: Are the Vedas useful for a person with knowledge of the Self?
Answers: To the Brahmana who has known the Self, all the Vedas are of as much use as a reservoir of water would be in a place where there is a flood.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: Your right is only to work, but not to its results; do not let the results of action be your motive, nor let your attachment be to inaction.

Questions: What is evenness of mind or equanimity?
Answers: Perform action, O Arjuna, being steadfast in Yoga, abandoning attachment and balanced in success and failure; evenness of mind is called Yoga.

Questions: What is the importance of equanimity?
Answers: Perform action, O Arjuna, being steadfast in Yoga, abandoning attachment and balanced in success and failure; evenness of mind is called Yoga.

Questions: How should action or karma be performed?
Answers: Far lower than the Yoga of wisdom is action, O Arjuna. Seek thou refuge in wisdom; wretched are those whose motive is the fruit.

Questions: What is the definition of Yoga?
Answers: Endowed with wisdom and evenness of mind, one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote yourself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action.

Questions: What happens to those who possess evenness of mind and are equanimous?
Answers: The wise, possessing knowledge, having abandoned the fruits of their actions, and being freed from the bonds of birth, go to the place which is beyond all evil.

Questions: What happens to those who have gone beyond the tangle of delusion?
Answers: When your intellect passes beyond the mire of delusion, then you will attain indifference to what has been heard and what has yet to be heard.

Questions: What happens to those whose whose intellect has been enlightened?
Answers: When your intellect, which is perplexed by the Vedic texts you have read, stands immovable and steady in the Self, then you will attain Self-realization.

Questions: What was Arjuna's first question after hearing about Karma Yoga and the state of equanimity?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, what is the description of one who has steady wisdom and is merged in the superconscious state? How does one of steady wisdom speak, how do they sit, and how do they walk?"

Questions: Who is said to possess firm wisdom?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "When a man completely casts off, O Arjuna, all the desires of the mind and is satisfied in the Self by the Self, then he is said to be one of steady wisdom."

Questions: Who is considered to be a sthitaprajna?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "When a man completely casts off, O Arjuna, all the desires of the mind and is satisfied in the Self by the Self, then he is said to be one of steady wisdom."

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?

Questions: What is the state of a person whose mind is not perturbed by pain?
Answers: He whose mind is not shaken by adversity, who does not long for pleasures, and is free from attachment, fear, and anger, is called a sage of steady wisdom.

Questions: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?
Answers: He who is everywhere without attachment, upon encountering anything good or bad, neither rejoices nor hastens; his wisdom is firm.

Questions: When is a person's wisdom said to be firmly established?
Answers: When, like the tortoise which withdraws all its limbs on all sides, he withdraws his senses from the sense-objects, then his wisdom becomes steady.

Questions: What happens to the senses when the Self becomes known?
Answers: The objects of the senses turn away from the abstinent man, leaving the longing behind; but his longing also turns away upon seeing the Supreme.

Questions: How powerful are the senses?
Answers: The turbulent senses, O Arjuna, can violently carry away the mind of a wise person, even though they are striving to control them.

Questions: Why do we need to control the senses?
Answers: Having restrained them all, he should sit steadfast, intent on Me; his wisdom is steady whose senses are under control.

Answers: When one thinks of objects, attachment to them arises; from attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.

Answers: Anger leads to delusion, which causes loss of memory; this, in turn, leads to the destruction of discrimination, resulting in destruction.

Questions: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects?
Answers: But the self-controlled man, moving among objects with the senses restrained and free from attraction and repulsion, attains peace.

Questions: How can we get over anger?
Answers: But the self-controlled man, moving among objects with the senses restrained and free from attraction and repulsion, attains peace.

Questions: How can we become serene?
Answers: But the self-controlled man, moving among objects with the senses restrained and free from attraction and repulsion, attains peace.

Questions: How is the state of a serene person?
Answers: In that peace, all pains are destroyed; for the intellect of the tranquil-minded soon becomes steady.

Questions: Why is the importance of contemplation of the Self or soul?
Answers: There is no knowledge of the Self for the unsteady, and no meditation is possible for the unsteady, and no peace for the unmeditative, and how can there be happiness for one who has no peace?

Questions: What happens to the mind when it follows the senses?
Answers: For the mind, which follows in the wake of the wandering senses, carries away his discrimination, as the wind carries away a boat on the waters.

Questions: What happens to the one whose senses are restrained?
Answers: Therefore, O mighty-armed Arjuna, his knowledge is steady whose senses are completely restrained from sense objects.

Questions: What is the difference between discerning sages and others?
Answers: That which is night to all beings, in that the self-controlled man is awake; when all beings are awake, that is night for the sage who sees.

Questions: Where is the analogy with an undisturbed sea mentioned in the Gita?
Answers: He attains peace into whom all desires enter, just as waters enter the ocean which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved; but not the man who is full of desires.

Questions: How can we attain peace?
Answers: That person attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of ownership, and without egoism.

Questions: What is the Brahmic state?
Answers: O son of Pritha, this is the eternal state, the Brahmic seat. Attaining this, one is not deluded. Being established in it, one attains oneness with Brahman even at the end of life.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: Arjuna said: If Thou thinkest that knowledge is superior to action, O Krishna, why then, O Kesava, doest Thou ask me to engage in this terrible action?

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: With this seemingly perplexing speech, you seem to be confusing my understanding; therefore, tell me one certain way by which I may attain bliss.

Questions: Is there any mention of Sankhya Yoga in the Gita?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "In this world, there is a twofold path, as I said before, O sinless one: the path of knowledge of the Sankhyas and the path of action of the Yogins."

Questions: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?
Answers: Man does not reach actionlessness by not performing actions; nor does he attain perfection by mere renunciation.

Questions: Can any person avoid doing action or work even for a moment?
Answers: Verily, no one can remain for even a moment without performing action; for everyone is made to act helplessly, indeed, by the qualities born of Nature.

Questions: Who is a deluded person?
Answers: He who, restraining the organs of action, sits thinking of the sense-objects in his mind, he of deluded understanding is called a hypocrite.

Questions: Who is an excellent person?
Answers: But whoever, controlling the senses by the mind, O Arjuna, engages himself in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment, he excels.

Questions: Is action superior to inaction?
Answers: Perform your bounden duty, for action is superior to inaction, and even the maintenance of the body would not be possible for you through inaction.

Questions: Why is it important to perform one's duties?
Answers: Perform your bounden duty, for action is superior to inaction, and even the maintenance of the body would not be possible for you through inaction.

Questions: When does work or action lead to bondage?
Answers: The world is bound by actions other than those performed for the sake of sacrifice; do thou, therefore, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), perform actions for that sake alone, free from attachment.

Questions: Why should we propagate our species?
Answers: The Creator, having in the beginning created mankind together with sacrifice, said, "By this shall you propagate; let this be the milch cow of your desires—the cow that yields all the desired objects."

Questions: What is the duty of ordinary human beings?
Answers: With this, nourish the gods, and may the gods nourish you; thus, nourishing each other, you shall attain the highest good.

Questions: Who is a thief?
Answers: The gods, nourished by the sacrifice, will give you the desired objects. So, he who enjoys the objects given by the gods without offering anything in return is indeed a thief.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: The righteous who eat the remnants of the sacrifice are freed from all sins; but those sinful ones who cook food solely for their own sake indeed consume sin.

Questions: What is the importance of food?
Answers: From food come forth beings; from rain, food is produced; from sacrifice arises rain, and sacrifice is born of action.

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: Know that action comes from Brahma, and Brahma comes from the Imperishable. Therefore, the all-pervasive Brahma ever rests in sacrifice.

Questions: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?
Answers: He who does not follow the wheel thus set in motion, who is of sinful life, rejoicing in the senses, lives in vain, O Arjuna.

Questions: Do people who are satisfied with the Self also need to perform all the worldly duties?
Answers: But for that man who rejoices only in the Self, who is satisfied with the Self and is content in the Self alone, indeed there is nothing to do.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: For him, there is no interest whatsoever in what is done or not done; nor does he depend on any being for any purpose.

Questions: Why is detachment important?
Answers: Therefore, without attachment, always perform the actions that should be done; for by performing actions without attachment, one reaches the Supreme.

Questions: What is the result of detachment?
Answers: Therefore, without attachment, always perform the actions that should be done; for by performing actions without attachment, one reaches the Supreme.

Questions: How did King Janaka reach perfection or salvation or liberation?
Answers: Janaka and others attained perfection indeed through action alone; even with the intention of protecting the masses, you should perform action.

Questions: What impact do great men have on others?
Answers: Whatever a great man does, others also do; whatever he establishes as the standard, the world follows.

Questions: Is God also bound by any duties towards the world?
Answers: There is nothing in the three worlds, O Arjuna, that needs to be done by Me, nor is there anything unattained that needs to be attained; yet I engage Myself in action.

Questions: Why does God continue to perform action?
Answers: For, should I not ever engage myself in action, unwearied, people would in every way follow my path, O Arjuna.

Questions: What will happen if God ceases to perform action?
Answers: These worlds would perish if I did not perform action; I would be the author of confusion of castes and destruction of these beings.

Questions: What should be the motivation for the wise men to work?
Answers: As the ignorant act out of attachment to action, O Bharata, so should the wise act without attachment, wishing for the welfare of the world.

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: Let no wise man unsettle the minds of ignorant people who are attached to action; he should engage them in all actions, himself fulfilling them with devotion.

Questions: Is action performed by the individual or by nature itself?
Answers: All actions are wrought in all cases by the qualities of Nature alone. He whose mind is deluded by egoism thinks, "I am the doer."

Questions: How does the knowledge of the Gunas lead to detachment?
Answers: But he who knows the Truth, O mighty-armed Arjuna, about the divisions of the qualities and their functions, knowing that the Gunas, as senses, move amidst the Gunas, as the sense-objects, is not attached.

Questions: How should the ignorant be treated?
Answers: Those deluded by the qualities of Nature are attached to the functions of the qualities. The man of perfect knowledge should not unsettle the foolish one who is of imperfect knowledge.

Questions: Where does Krishna first talk about the concept of surrender?
Answers: Renouncing all actions in Me, with the mind centered on the Self, free from hope and egoism, and from mental fever, fight thou.

Questions: Where does Krishna first talk about the concept of faith?
Answers: Those who constantly practice this teaching of Mine with faith and without caviling, they too are freed from actions.

Questions: What happens to those who do not follow the principle of Karma Yoga?
Answers: But those who criticize My teaching and do not practice it, deprived of all knowledge and lacking discernment, know them to be doomed to destruction.

Questions: Should innate desires be repressed?
Answers: Even a wise man acts in accordance with his own nature; beings will follow their nature; what can restraint do?

Questions: How should one treat his or her own senses?
Answers: Attachment and aversion for the objects of the senses abide in the senses; let no one come under their sway; for, they are his enemies.

Questions: Why is important to perform one's own duty?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, though devoid of merit, than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one's own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear.

Questions: How can we become successful?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, though devoid of merit, than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one's own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear.

Questions: How can we achieve success?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, though devoid of merit, than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one's own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear.

Questions: What did Arjuna ask about sin?
Answers: Arjuna said, "But what compels man to commit sin, even against his wishes, O Varshneya (Krishna), as if constrained by force?"

Questions: What is the primary cause of sin?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "It is desire and it is anger, both of the quality of Rajas, all-devouring and all-sinful; know this as the foe here in this world."

Questions: What is desire?
Answers: As fire is enveloped by smoke, as a mirror is covered by dust, and as an embryo is surrounded by the amniotic sac, so is this enveloped by that.

Questions: What is the cause of ignorance?
Answers: As fire is enveloped by smoke, as a mirror is covered by dust, and as an embryo is surrounded by the amniotic sac, so is this enveloped by that.

Questions: Is there any relation between desires and ignorance?
Answers: As fire is enveloped by smoke, as a mirror is covered by dust, and as an embryo is surrounded by the amniotic sac, so is this enveloped by that.

Questions: Can desires be gratified?
Answers: O Arjuna, wisdom is enveloped by this constant enemy of the wise, in the form of desire, which is insatiable like fire.

Questions: Why are desires so hard to satisfy?
Answers: O Arjuna, wisdom is enveloped by this constant enemy of the wise, in the form of desire, which is insatiable like fire.

Questions: How does desire overpowers the Self?
Answers: The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be its seat; through these, it deludes the embodied one, veiling their wisdom.

Questions: Why is it important to control the desires?
Answers: Therefore, O best of the Bharatas, control your senses first and then kill this sinful thing, which destroys knowledge and realization.

Questions: Which is greater, the Self or the intellect?
Answers: They say that the senses are superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intellect is superior to the mind; and He (the Self) is superior even to the intellect.

Questions: How can one control the desires?
Answers: Thus, knowing Him who is superior to the intellect and restraining the self by the Self, slay thou, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the enemy in the form of desire, hard to conquer.

Questions: Whom did Krishna first teach Yoga?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "I taught this imperishable Yoga to Vivasvan; he then told it to Manu; Manu proclaimed it to Ikshvaku.

Questions: How did the knowledge of Yoga get lost?
Answers: This, handed down in regular succession by the royal sages, was known. This Yoga, however, has been lost here over time, O Parantapa (burner of the foes).

Questions: Why was Krishna teaching Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: That same ancient yoga has been today taught to you by me, for you are my devotee and my friend; it is the supreme secret.

Questions: What was Arjuna's reaction on hearing that Krishna taught Yoga to Vivasvan and other ancestors?
Answers: Arjuna said, "Later was Thy birth, and prior to it was the birth of Vivasvan (the Sun); how am I to understand that Thou hast taught this Yoga from the beginning?"

Questions: Does God also have multiple births?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Many births of Mine have passed, as well as of thine, O Arjuna; I know them all, but thou knowest not, O Parantapa (scorcher of foes)."

Questions: What is the concept of Avatar or reincarnation?
Answers: Though I am unborn and of imperishable nature, and though I am the Lord of all beings, yet, governing my own nature, I am born by my own Maya.

Questions: Can God take birth in a human form?
Answers: Though I am unborn and of imperishable nature, and though I am the Lord of all beings, yet, governing my own nature, I am born by my own Maya.

Questions: Is it possible for God to be born on this earth?
Answers: Though I am unborn and of imperishable nature, and though I am the Lord of all beings, yet, governing my own nature, I am born by my own Maya.

Questions: When and why does God incarnate?
Answers: Whenever there is a decline of righteousness and an increase of unrighteousness, O Arjuna, then I manifest Myself.

Questions: Will Sanatana Dharma be eradicated some day?
Answers: Whenever there is a decline of righteousness and an increase of unrighteousness, O Arjuna, then I manifest Myself.

Questions: Can Hinduism be eradicated?
Answers: Whenever there is a decline of righteousness and an increase of unrighteousness, O Arjuna, then I manifest Myself.

Questions: Why does God incarnate?
Answers: For the protection of the good, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of righteousness, I am born in every age.

Questions: Does God do anything to protect good people?
Answers: For the protection of the good, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of righteousness, I am born in every age.

Questions: Can good people expect any help from God?
Answers: For the protection of the good, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of righteousness, I am born in every age.

Questions: What happens to those who know about God's incarnations or Avatars?
Answers: He who thus knows, in their true light, My divine birth and actions, having abandoned the body, is not born again; he comes to Me, O Arjuna.

Questions: Have people actually attained liberation or salvation?
Answers: Freed from attachment, fear, and anger, absorbed in Me, taking refuge in Me, purified by the fire of knowledge, many have attained My Being.

Questions: Is there a single path to attain God?
Answers: In whatever way men approach Me, even so do I reward them; My path do men tread in all ways, O Arjuna.

Questions: What happens to those who perform rituals?
Answers: Those who long for success in action in this world sacrifice to the gods; for success is quickly attained by men through action.

Questions: What is the concept of varna or caste?
Answers: The fourfold caste has been created by Me according to the differentiation of Guna and Karma; though I am the author of it, know Me as non-doer and immutable.

Questions: Does God also get bound by his actions?
Answers: Actions do not taint Me, nor do I have a desire for the fruit of actions. He who knows Me thus is not bound by actions.

Questions: Did spiritual seekers of ancient times abstain from work or action?
Answers: Having known this, the ancient seekers of freedom also performed action; therefore, do thou also perform action, as the ancients did in days of yore.

Questions: Is it easy to understand the difference between action and inaction?
Answers: What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused about this. Therefore, I shall teach you the nature of action and inaction, by knowing which you will be liberated from the evil of Samsara, the wheel of birth and death.

Questions: Why is the way of action so mysterious?
Answers: For verily, the true nature of action enjoined by the scriptures should be known, as well as that of forbidden or unlawful action, and of inaction; the nature of action is hard to understand.

Questions: What is the relation between action and inaction?
Answers: He who sees inaction in action and action in inaction, he is wise among men; he is a yogi and performer of all actions.

Questions: Who is a sage or pandit?
Answers: He whose undertakings are all devoid of desires and selfish purposes, and whose actions have been burned by the fire of knowledge, the wise call him a sage.

Questions: What is the secret of inaction in action?
Answers: Having abandoned attachment to the fruits of the action, ever content, depending on nothing, he does not do anything even while being engaged in activity.

Questions: How do sages stay away from evil?
Answers: Without hope, controlling the mind and the self, having abandoned all covetousness, and performing only bodily actions, one incurs no sin.

Questions: How do sages remain free from bondage?
Answers: Content with what comes to him without effort, free from the pairs of opposites and envy, even-minded in success and failure, he acts yet is not bound.

Questions: How do sages dissolve their Karma?
Answers: To one who is devoid of attachment, who is liberated, whose mind is established in knowledge, and who works for the sake of sacrifice (for the sake of God), the whole action is dissolved.

Questions: What is the concept of Brahman?
Answers: Brahman is the oblation; Brahman is the melted butter (ghee); by Brahman is the oblation poured into the fire of Brahman; Brahman indeed shall be attained by one who always sees Brahman in action.

Questions: What are the different kinds of sacrifices that Yogis perform?
Answers: Some yogis perform sacrifice to the gods alone; while others, who have realized the Self, offer the Self as sacrifice in the fire of Brahman alone.

Questions: What are the different kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?
Answers: Some again offer the organ of hearing and other senses as a sacrifice in the fire of restraint; others offer sound and other objects of the senses as a sacrifice in the fire of the senses.

Questions: What are the kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?
Answers: Others again sacrifice all the functions of the senses and those of the breath (vital energy, or Prana) in the fire of the Yoga of self-restraint, kindled by knowledge.

Questions: What are the kinds of sacrifices that Yogis perform?
Answers: Others again offer wealth, austerity, and Yoga as sacrifice, while ascetics of self-restraint and rigid vows offer the study of scriptures and knowledge as sacrifice.

Questions: How do Yogis perform various austerities?
Answers: Others offer as sacrifice the outgoing breath into the incoming, and the incoming into the outgoing, restraining the flow of the outgoing and the incoming breaths, solely absorbed in the restraint of the breath.

Questions: What happens to those who subsist on sacrificial food?
Answers: Others who regulate their diet offer life-breaths in each life-breath. All these are knowers of sacrifice, whose sins are destroyed through sacrifice.

Questions: What happens to those who do not perform any sactifices?
Answers: Those who eat the remnants of the sacrifice, which are like nectar, go to the eternal Brahman. This world is not for the one who does not perform sacrifice; how then can they have the other, O Arjuna?

Questions: Is there only one correct way of performing sacrifices?
Answers: Thus, manifold sacrifices are spread out before Brahman at the face of Brahman. Know them all to be born of action, and thus knowing, you shall be liberated.

Questions: Which is the highest sacrifice?
Answers: Superior is wisdom-sacrifice to the sacrifice with objects, O Parantapa (scorcher of the foes). All actions in their entirety, O Arjuna, culminate in knowledge.

Questions: How is the sacrifice of knowledge performed?
Answers: Know that the wise who have realized the truth will instruct thee in that knowledge through long prostration, supplication, and service.

Questions: What happens to those who know how to perform the sacrifice of knowledge?
Answers: Knowing that thou shalt not, O Arjuna, again be deluded like this; and by that thou shalt see all beings in thyself and also in me.

Questions: How can sinners attain liberation or salvation?
Answers: Even if thou art the most sinful of all sinners, yet thou shalt surely cross over all sins by the raft of knowledge.

Questions: Is there any hope for sinners?
Answers: Even if thou art the most sinful of all sinners, yet thou shalt surely cross over all sins by the raft of knowledge.

Questions: What does knowledge do to Karma?
Answers: As the blazing fire reduces fuel to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all actions to ash.

Questions: Which is the best or highest purifier?
Answers: Verily, there is no purifier in this world like knowledge. He who is perfected in Yoga finds it within the Self in due time.

Questions: What happens to those who have faith?
Answers: The one who is full of faith, devoted to it, and has subdued their senses obtains this knowledge; and upon obtaining the knowledge, they attain the supreme peace immediately.

Questions: What happens to those who do not have faith?
Answers: The ignorant, the faithless, and the doubting self go to destruction; there is neither this world nor the other, nor happiness for the doubting one.

Questions: What happens to those who practice Karma Yoga?
Answers: He who has renounced actions through Yoga, whose doubts have been dispelled by knowledge, and who is self-possessed—such a one is not bound by actions, O Arjuna.

Questions: How to get rid of doubts about the Self?
Answers: Therefore, with the sword of knowledge (of the Self), cut asunder the doubt of the self, born of ignorance, residing in your heart, and take refuge in Yoga. Arise, O Arjuna!

Questions: What did Arjuna ask after knowing in detail about the path of knowledge and the path of action?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, you praise renunciation of actions and also yoga. Please tell me conclusively which is better of the two."

Questions: Is Karma Yoga better than renunciation of actions?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Renunciation and the Yoga of action both lead to the highest bliss; but of the two, the Yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action."

Questions: How can one be free from bondage?
Answers: He should be known as a perpetual Sannyasi who neither hates nor desires; for, free from the pairs of opposites, O mighty-armed Arjuna, he is easily freed from bondage.

Questions: Is Sankhya Yoga different from Karma Yoga?
Answers: Children, not the wise, speak of knowledge and the Yoga of action, or the performance of action, as though they are distinct and different; he who is truly established in one, obtains the fruits of both.

Questions: Do the Sankhya Yogis reach the same state as the Karma Yogis?
Answers: That place which is reached by the Sankhyas or the Jnanis is also reached by the Yogis (Karma Yogis). He who sees knowledge and the performance of action (Karma Yoga) as one, sees truly.

Questions: Why is renunciation so hard?
Answers: But, O mighty-armed Arjuna, renunciation is hard to attain without Yoga; the sage who is in harmony with Yoga quickly goes to Brahman.

Questions: How can one remain untainted and detached while performing action?
Answers: He who is devoted to the path of action, whose mind is pure, who has conquered the self, who has subdued his senses, and who realizes his Self as the Self in all beings, though acting, is not tainted.

Questions: How should one perform action?
Answers: "I do nothing at all," thus would the harmonized knower of Truth think, seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, going, sleeping, and breathing.

Questions: Can the senses perceive the mind?
Answers: Speaking, letting go, seizing, opening, and closing the eyes, one should be convinced that the senses move among the sense-objects.

Questions: What happens to those who act without attachment?
Answers: He who does actions, offering them to Brahman and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus leaf is not tainted by water.

Questions: Why do Yogis perform action?
Answers: Yogis, having abandoned attachment, perform actions only through the body, mind, intellect, and even the senses, for the purification of the self.

Questions: What is the difference between a Yogi and an ordinary person?
Answers: The one who is united (the well-poised or harmonized) having abandoned the fruit of action attains eternal peace; whereas the one who is not united (the unsteady or unbalanced), impelled by desire and attached to the fruit, is bound.

Questions: What happens to a Yogi who has renounced all fruits of his actions?
Answers: The one who is united (the well-poised or harmonized) having abandoned the fruit of action attains eternal peace; whereas the one who is not united (the unsteady or unbalanced), impelled by desire and attached to the fruit, is bound.

Questions: What happens to a detached Yogi?
Answers: The one who is united (the well-poised or harmonized) having abandoned the fruit of action attains eternal peace; whereas the one who is not united (the unsteady or unbalanced), impelled by desire and attached to the fruit, is bound.

Questions: What happens to a person who is unable to give up attachment?
Answers: The one who is united (the well-poised or harmonized) having abandoned the fruit of action attains eternal peace; whereas the one who is not united (the unsteady or unbalanced), impelled by desire and attached to the fruit, is bound.

Questions: What kind of attitude should one have towards work and duty?
Answers: Mentally renouncing all actions and being self-controlled, the embodied one happily rests in the nine-gated city, neither acting nor causing others (body and senses) to act.

Questions: Does the Self create actions and their fruits or results?
Answers: Neither does the Lord create agency nor actions for the world, nor union with the fruits of actions; rather, it is Nature that acts.

Questions: Does God keep track of a person's sins and merits?
Answers: The Lord takes neither the demerit nor the merit of any; knowledge is enveloped by ignorance, and beings are deluded.

Questions: How can ignorance be destroyed?
Answers: But to those whose ignorance is destroyed by knowledge of the Self, like the sun, knowledge reveals the Supreme Brahman.

Questions: How can impurities be removed?
Answers: Their intellect absorbed in That, their self being That, established in That, with That as their supreme goal, they go whence there is no return, their sins dispelled by knowledge.

Questions: How do sages look upon saints and sinners?
Answers: Sages look with an equal eye on a Brahmana endowed with learning and humility, on a cow, an elephant, a dog, and even an outcaste.

Questions: How do equanimous people see the world?
Answers: Even here in this world, those whose minds rest in reality overcome birth; Brahman is indeed spotless and real; therefore they are established in Brahman.

Questions: How do equanimous people react towards pleasure and pain?
Answers: Resting in Brahman, with a steady intellect and undeluded, the knower of Brahman neither rejoices upon obtaining what is pleasant nor grieves upon obtaining what is unpleasant.

Questions: How can one enjoy endless happiness?
Answers: With the self unattached to external contacts, he finds happiness in the Self; with the self engaged in the meditation of Brahman, he attains endless happiness.

Questions: Why is it necessary to be detached from pleasure?
Answers: The enjoyments that arise from contact are only sources of pain, for they have a beginning and an end, O Arjuna; the wise do not rejoice in them.

Questions: Who is a Yogi?
Answers: He who is able, while still here in this world, to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before the liberation from the body, he is a Yogi, and he is a happy man.

Questions: Who is happy?
Answers: He who is able, while still here in this world, to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before the liberation from the body, he is a Yogi, and he is a happy man.

Questions: What beings happiness?
Answers: He who is able, while still here in this world, to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before the liberation from the body, he is a Yogi, and he is a happy man.

Questions: What brings joy?
Answers: He who is able, while still here in this world, to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before the liberation from the body, he is a Yogi, and he is a happy man.

Questions: Who attains Moksha?
Answers: He who is happy within, who rejoices within, and who is illuminated within, that Yogi attains absolute freedom, or Moksha, becoming Brahman himself.

Questions: Who attains absolute freedom?
Answers: He who is happy within, who rejoices within, and who is illuminated within, that Yogi attains absolute freedom, or Moksha, becoming Brahman himself.

Questions: Who attains the bliss of Brahman?
Answers: The sages obtain absolute freedom or Moksha when their sins have been destroyed, their dualities have been torn asunder, they are self-controlled, and they are intent on the welfare of all beings.

Questions: Who achieves absolute freedom?
Answers: Absolute freedom exists on all sides for those self-controlled ascetics who are free from desire and anger, who have controlled their thoughts, and who have realized the Self.

Questions: How should one meditate?
Answers: Shutting out all external contacts and fixing the gaze between the eyebrows, realizing the outgoing and incoming breaths moving within the nostrils.

Questions: How does a sage become eternally free?
Answers: With the senses, mind, and intellect ever controlled, having liberation as their supreme goal, free from desire, fear, and anger, the sage is truly liberated forever.

Questions: How do the sages view God?
Answers: He who knows Me as the enjoyer of sacrifices and austerities, the great Lord of all the worlds, and the friend of all beings, attains peace.

Questions: Who is a sannyasin?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said: He who performs his bounden duty without depending on the fruits of his actions—he is a sannyasi and a yogi, not he who is without fire and without action.

Questions: what is the difference between the path of knowledge and Karma Yoga?
Answers: Do you, O Arjuna, know that Yoga is what they call renunciation; no one indeed becomes a Yogi who has not renounced their thoughts.

Questions: for how long should a yogi continue to perform action?
Answers: For a sage who wishes to attain to Yoga, action is said to be the means; for the same sage who has attained Yoga, inaction is said to be the means.

Questions: when is a person said to be established in Yoga?
Answers: When a person is not attached to the sense-objects or to actions, having renounced all thoughts, then they are said to have attained Yoga.

Questions: Can our self be our enemy?
Answers: One should raise oneself by one's own self alone; let not one lower oneself; for the self alone is one's own friend, and the self alone is one's own enemy.
